instruction:
In February 1998, the 40-year-old Saudi exile Usama  Bin Laden and a fugitive Egyptian physician, Ayman al Zawahiri, arranged from their Afghan headquarters for an Arabic newspaper in London to publish what they termed a fatwa issued in the name of a "World Islamic Front." A fatwa is normally an interpretation of Islamic law by a respected Islamic authority, but neither  Bin Laden, Zawahiri, nor the three others who signed this statement were scholars of Islamic law. Claiming that America had declared war against God and his messenger, they called for the murder of any American, anywhere on earth, as the "individual duty for every Muslim who can do it in any country in which it is possible to do it." Three months later, when interviewed in Afghanistan by ABC-TV,  Bin Laden enlarged on these themes. He claimed it was more important for Muslims to kill Americans than to kill other infidels." It is far better for anyone to kill a single American soldier than to squander his efforts on other activities," he said. Asked whether he approved of terrorism and of attacks on civilians, he replied:"We believe that the worst thieves in the world today and the worst terrorists are the Americans. Nothing could stop you except perhaps retaliation in kind. We do not have to differentiate between military or civilian. As far as we are concerned, they are all targets." Note: Islamic names often do not follow the Western practice of the consistent use of surnames. Given the variety of names we mention, we chose to refer to individuals by the last word in the names by which they are known: Nawaf al Hazmi as Hazmi, for instance, omitting the article "al" that would be part of their name in their own societies. We generally make an exception for the more familiar English usage of "Bin" as part of a last name, as in  Bin Laden. Further, there is no universally accepted way to transliterate Arabic words and names into English. We have relied on a mix of common sense, the sound of the name in Arabic, and common usage in source materials, the press, or government documents. When we quote from a source document, we use its transliteration, e.g.,"al Qida" instead of al Qaeda. Though novel for its open endorsement of indiscriminate killing,  Bin Laden's 1998 declaration was only the latest in the long series of his public and private calls since 1992 that singled out the United States for attack. In August 1996,  Bin Laden had issued his own self-styled fatwa calling on Muslims to drive American soldiers out of Saudi Arabia. 
What question would one ask from this paragraph?
output: One possible question that could be asked from this paragraph is: What factors and motivations led Usama Bin Laden and Ayman al Zawahiri to issue a fatwa against the United States, and how did their views evolve over time leading up to the 1998 declaration encouraging indiscriminate killing of Americans?

instruction:
Article: Fresh snow weighs less than older snow so you should clear snow as soon as it has fallen. As snow sits on the ground it compacts and becomes wet, making it heavier. It can also then turn into ice and become very difficult to remove.  Wait until the snowplow has come by before finishing the driveway. A snowplow will usually "plow in" the driveway at least a bit, pushing more snow onto the edge of your driveway. It can be easier to deal with just clearing the driveway once. Use extra care when shoveling snow pushed onto your driveway by the plow. Plows pack the snow, making it much heavier than undisturbed, freshly fallen snow. One shovelful of snow can weigh 20 pounds (9kg) or more! You will need to consider what is the most efficient snow removal plan. You will also have to avoid piling snow where you'll have to just remove it again, so do not block access to snow that still needs to be cleared. If you are clearing a rectangle, it is better to work from the center out. First clear a strip of snow around the perimeter of the rectangle. Then, starting in the center, push snow towards the cleared area. From there, lift the snow out of the area. Use a brush to get snow off cars before clearing around the car to prevent extra work. Pushing snow is much easier than lifting and can reduce the risk of injury. If you begin early and if the snow is not too deep, then it is better to simply push it off driveways and sidewalks. This is a good way to clear away snow while it is still falling, to reduce accumulation. Spread your hands far apart on the handle, with one hand close to the blade. This will provide more leverage while lifting snow. If you need to dig (to get to your car, for instance), dig using a steady, easy motion. If you are "pushing" (as you might when clearing a driveway), hold your shovel at a slight angle and begin making passes back and forth width-wise along your driveway. You should rarely need to move your shovel above waist height. Make sure you clear around your mailbox every time it snows. If your mail carrier cannot easily reach your mailbox, then they cannot deliver your mail! Be careful with salt, as it can hurt your lawn, landscaping, and your watershed. It can also damage driveways and other paved areas. Use salt only if the temperature is warm enough (above 0 degrees F/-17 degrees C).  Sand provides traction, but if more snow falls on top, it will become useless. Salting the ground before or during a storm can actually increase the amount of snow on your sidewalks and driveways because dry snow sticks to a salted paved area but does not stick to an unsalted paved area.

What is a summary?
output: A summary of the article involves highlighting the key points and tips regarding snow removal. Clearing fresh snow as soon as it falls is important, as it weighs less and is easier to remove before it compacts and turns into ice. Wait until the snowplow comes by before finishing your driveway to avoid having to clear it again. Exercise caution when shoveling snow pushed by the plow, as it is heavier than freshly fallen snow. Develop an efficient snow removal plan, working from the center of a rectangle outwards. Use a brush to clear snow off cars first, and try pushing snow instead of lifting to reduce injury risk. Keep your hands spread far on the handle for better leverage when lifting snow. Ensure your mailbox is accessible for mail delivery. Be careful when using salt, as it can damage your lawn, landscaping, and paved areas, and is only effective above 0 degrees F/-17 degrees C. Use sand for traction but be aware that it becomes useless if more snow falls on top. Salting before or during a storm may lead to more snow accumulation.

In 1884, Germany formally took possession of the northeast quarter of the island and it became known as German New Guinea. In 1884, a British protectorate was proclaimed over Papua -- the southern coast of New Guinea. The protectorate, called British New Guinea, was annexed outright on 4 September 1888 and possession passed to the newly federated Commonwealth of Australia in 1902 and British New Guinea became the Australian Territory of Papua, with Australian administration beginning in 1906.

Can we conclude that was papua new guinea ever part of australia?
output:
Okay, let me explain this in a simple way. A long time ago, there was a big island called New Guinea. People from different countries - Germany and Britain - wanted to take care of parts of this big island. 

The Germany people took care of the top part and called it German New Guinea. The Britain people took care of the bottom part, called it British New Guinea, and later gave it to their friends, the Australians. When Australia took care of the bottom part, they called it the Australian Territory of Papua. 

So, yes, we can say that once upon a time, a part of Papua New Guinea (the bottom part) was connected with Australia, like how friends look after each other's things. But now, Papua New Guinea is its own country and not a part of Australia anymore.

instruction:
Answer by taking a quote from the following article:

Josie and the Pussycats (initially published as She's Josie and Josie) is a teen-humor comic book about a fictional rock band, created by Dan DeCarlo and published by Archie Comics. It was published from 1963 until 1982; since then, a number of one-shot issues have appeared without regularity. A second series, set in the New Riverdale universe, launched in September 2016. The series was adapted into a Saturday morning cartoon by Hanna-Barbera Productions in 1970 and a live-action motion picture by Universal Studios and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in 2001.

In March 2005, Archie Comics announced that a manga version of the title would be published, with art by Tania del Rio, who was also responsible for the manga makeover of Sabrina, the Teenage Witch. The first such "Josie and the Pussycasts" story, "Opening Act" ran in Tales from Riverdale Digest #3 (August 2005) The band had previously appeared in manga form in issue Sabrina, The Teenage Witch #67 (August 2005).  In Archie & Friends #96 (January 2006) the origin of the Pussycats was retconned. The manga version implies that none of the characters previously knew each other. Josie Jones was cut from the school choir, but met Valerie Smith and the two founded the band. They recruited Melody, whose idea it was to wear cat outfits. The band was not doing well at first, but Alex liked the group, though Alexandra could tell he was more interested in Josie. Alex's father let him be the manager as long as he did not use his wealth to help make them stars. In Sabrina the Teenage Witch #72 (February 2006), a stranger named Alan helped carry their equipment. Josie, already attracted to Alan, jealously thought there was an attraction between Alan and Melody. Alex hired him as their stagehand.  The manga focused on the group's attempt to reach fame rather than on their career after they have already achieved it. It featured characters not seen in other comics, including Alan's younger sister Alison and the rival group the Vixens. The manga version was not popular among readers, who preferred the traditional style. Its final appearance was in Archie & Friends #104 (December 2006). A Katy Keene revival replaced it (both featured alongside each other in the latter part of the manga's run), though it, too, did not last.

was the manga version different than the first version?
output: Yes, the manga version of Josie and the Pussycats was different from the first version. As taken from the article, "In Archie & Friends #96 (January 2006) the origin of the Pussycats was retconned. The manga version implies that none of the characters previously knew each other." The manga focused on the group's attempt to reach fame rather than on their career after they already achieved it. It also featured new characters, such as Alan's younger sister Alison and the rival group the Vixens. However, the manga version was not popular among readers, who preferred the traditional style, and its final appearance was in Archie & Friends #104 (December 2006).

instruction:
Please answer a question about the following article about Premier League:

The team placed fifth in the Premier League automatically qualifies for the UEFA Europa League, and the sixth and seventh-placed teams can also qualify, depending on the winners of the two domestic cup competitions i.e. the FA Cup and the Capital One Cup (League Cup). Two Europa League places are reserved for the winners of each tournament; if the winner of either the FA Cup or League Cup qualifies for the Champions League, then that place will go to the next-best placed finisher in the Premier League. A further place in the UEFA Europa League is also available via the Fair Play initiative. If the Premier League has one of the three highest Fair Play rankings in Europe, the highest ranked team in the Premier League Fair Play standings which has not already qualified for Europe will automatically qualify for the UEFA Europa League first qualifying round.

The team which has the highest ranking in the Fair Play standings is guaranteed qualification for which qualifying round in the Europa League?
output: The team with the highest ranking in the Fair Play standings is guaranteed qualification for the first qualifying round in the Europa League.

instruction:
Thomson was born in Glasgow, Scotland, the youngest of six children. He arrived in the United States two years later. His father, a cabinet maker, had moved to New York City shortly before Bobby's birth and sent for his family in 1925. Thomson grew up on Staten Island in New York City and signed with the New York Giants for a $100 bonus right out of Curtis High School in 1942.

Longstanding rumors that the Giants engaged in systematic sign stealing during the second half of the 1951 season were confirmed in 2001. Several players told the Wall Street Journal that beginning on July 20, the team used a telescope, manned by coach Herman Franks in the Giants clubhouse behind center field, to steal the finger signals of opposing catchers. Stolen signs were relayed to the Giants dugout via a buzzer wire. Joshua Prager, the author of the Journal article, outlined the evidence in greater detail in a 2008 book.  Although Thomson always insisted that he had no foreknowledge of Branca's pitch, Sal Yvars told Prager that he relayed Rube Walker's fastball sign to Thomson. Branca was privately skeptical of Thomson's denials but made no public comment at the time. Later he told The New York Times, "I didn't want to diminish a legendary moment in baseball. And even if Bobby knew what was coming, he had to hit it.... Knowing the pitch doesn't always help." Whether the telescope-and-buzzer system contributed significantly to the Giants' late-season 37-7 win streak remains a subject of debate. Prager notes in his book that sign stealing was not specifically forbidden by MLB rules at the time and, moral issues aside, "...has been a part of baseball since its inception". Sign stealing using optical or other mechanical aids was outlawed by MLB in 1961.  Thomson however, late in his life, rebuked his prior claims of not receiving the sign on the Shot Heard 'Round the World, and admitted that the sign was received.

What was the controversy about?
output:
The controversy surrounding Bobby Thomson's "Shot Heard 'Round the World" in the 1951 baseball season revolves around the allegations of systematic sign stealing by the New York Giants during the second half of the season. Sign stealing, in this context, refers to the practice of observing and decoding the signals given by the opposing team's catcher to the pitcher and relaying the information to the batter, giving them an advantage to know what type of pitch is coming. 

In 2001, several former Giants players confirmed to the Wall Street Journal that starting on July 20, 1951, the team used a telescope manned by coach Herman Franks in the clubhouse behind center field to steal the finger signals of the opposing catchers. These stolen signs were then relayed to the Giants' dugout via a buzzer wire. Joshua Prager, the author of the Journal article, presented more detailed evidence in his 2008 book.

Bobby Thomson had always insisted that he had no prior knowledge of Ralph Branca's pitch, but Sal Yvars claimed that he relayed Rube Walker's fastball sign to Thomson before the famous home run. Branca, the Brooklyn Dodgers' pitcher who threw the pitch, was privately skeptical of Thomson's denials but chose not to publicly challenge the legitimacy of the "Shot Heard 'Round the World" at the time.

The controversy around this event raises questions about the ethics and fairness in the game of baseball. While sign stealing without aid was not specifically forbidden by Major League Baseball (MLB) rules at the time and has been a part of the sport since its inception, the use of optical or mechanical aids to steal signs was eventually outlawed by MLB in 1961.

Towards the end of his life, Bobby Thomson changed his stance and admitted to receiving the stolen sign on the "Shot Heard 'Round the World," lending credibility to the controversy and raising questions about the extent to which the Giants' late-season 37-7 win streak was aided by their sign-stealing tactics. Ultimately, the controversy surrounding the historic moment highlights the ethical dilemmas and complexities that can arise in competitive sports.

instruction:
Math problem: Solve 355*r - 4793 - 6922 = -355 for r.
What is the solution?
output:
Certainly! I'd be happy to help you solve this math problem. To start, let's rewrite the equation as:

355r - 4793 - 6922 = -355

First, let's add 4793 and 6922 to both sides of the equation to eliminate the negative terms:

355r = 4793 + 6922 + (-355)

This gives us:

355r = 11717

Next, let's divide both sides of the equation by 355 to solve for r:

r = 11717 / 355

This gives us:

r = 33

So, the solution to the equation 355r - 4793 - 6922 = -355 for r is r = 33.

instruction:
The day after the Pact was signed, the French and British military negotiation delegation urgently requested a meeting with Soviet military negotiator Kliment Voroshilov. On August 25, Voroshilov told them "[i]n view of the changed political situation, no useful purpose can be served in continuing the conversation." That day, Hitler told the British ambassador to Berlin that the pact with the Soviets prevented Germany from facing a two front war, changing the strategic situation from that in World War I, and that Britain should accept his demands regarding Poland.
Is there an answer to this question (If it cannot be answered, say "unanswerable"): What was the response of Kliment Voroshilov in regards to further conversations without Britain and France?
output:
Based on the information provided, there is an answer to this question.

According to the text, on August 25, 1939, Soviet military negotiator Kliment Voroshilov told the French and British military negotiation delegation that "no useful purpose can be served in continuing the conversation" in view of the changed political situation. This suggests that Voroshilov was not interested in continuing negotiations with France and Britain.

It is worth noting that the Pact between Germany and the Soviet Union had already been signed on August 23, 1939, and it is likely that Voroshilov's statement was a reflection of the new political reality that had been created by this agreement. The Pact had effectively neutralized the possibility of a two-front war against Germany, and Voroshilov may have seen no need to continue negotiations with France and Britain in light of this new situation.

Therefore, the response of Kliment Voroshilov in regards to further conversations without Britain and France was that he did not see any useful purpose in continuing them.

instruction:
Healthy and happy employees would mean more productivity energy and positivity at the workplace

Could you correct the punctuation please?
output:
Certainly! Here's the corrected sentence:

Healthy and happy employees would mean more productivity, energy, and positivity at the workplace.

Now, let me provide a detailed and long answer to the task at hand.

Having healthy and happy employees is crucial for the success of any organization. When employees are healthy and happy, they are more productive, have more energy, and exude positivity, all of which contribute to a thriving workplace.

Firstly, healthy employees are more productive. When employees are physically healthy, they are able to focus better, work longer hours without feeling fatigued, and are more motivated to complete tasks. A study by the World Health Organization found that for every dollar invested in health and wellness programs, employers saw an average return on investment of $3.27 in the form of increased productivity. This is because healthy employees are more productive, and they are less likely to take sick days or need to take breaks throughout the day.

Secondly, happy employees have more energy. When employees are happy, they are more motivated, engaged, and have the energy to tackle challenging tasks. A study by the University of Warwick found that happy employees are 12% more productive than their unhappy counterparts. This is because happiness stimulates the brain's reward system, which releases chemicals that make us feel good and motivate us to work harder. Happy employees are also less likely to experience burnout, which can lead to decreased productivity and increased absenteeism.

Thirdly, positivity in the workplace is contagious. When employees are happy and positive, they are more likely to spread that positivity to their colleagues, creating a ripple effect that can lead to a more productive and successful workplace. A study by the University of California found that positive emotions in the workplace can lead to increased collaboration, creativity, and innovation. This is because positive emotions broaden our attention, increase our openness to new experiences, and enhance our ability to think outside the box.

Furthermore, healthy and happy employees are more likely to stay with their current employer. A study by the Society for Human Resource Management found that employees who are happy and healthy are more likely to be engaged in their work and have lower rates of turnover. This is because happy and healthy employees are more likely to feel valued and appreciated by their employer, which can lead to increased job satisfaction and reduced absenteeism.

In addition, healthy and happy employees are more likely to be creative and innovative. A study by the University of Michigan found that happy employees are more likely to generate novel and creative solutions to problems. This is because happy employees are more likely to be open to new experiences and are more likely to take risks, which can lead to increased innovation and productivity.

Finally, healthy and happy employees are more likely to be good ambassadors for their employer. When employees are happy and healthy, they are more likely to share their positive experiences with others, which can lead to increased brand recognition and a stronger reputation for the employer. This is because happy employees are more likely to be engaged in their work and are more likely to feel valued and appreciated by their employer, which can lead to increased job satisfaction and reduced absenteeism.

In conclusion, healthy and happy employees are essential for a thriving workplace. When employees are healthy and happy, they are more productive, have more energy, and exude positivity, all of which contribute to a successful and profitable organization. Therefore, it is crucial for employers to prioritize the health and well-being of their employees, and to create a workplace culture that supports and promotes the physical, mental, and emotional well-being of their employees. By doing so, employers can reap the many benefits of healthy and happy employees, including increased productivity, creativity, innovation, and employee retention.

instruction: I read this background article the other day: Insecticide control of aphids is difficult, as they breed rapidly, so even small areas missed may enable the population to recover promptly. Aphids may occupy the undersides of leaves where spray misses them, while systemic insecticides do not move satisfactorily into flower petals. Finally, some aphid species are resistant to common insecticide classes including carbamates, organophosphates, and pyrethroids.For small backyard infestations, spraying plants thoroughly with a strong water jet every few days may be sufficient protection. An insecticidal soap solution can be an effective household remedy to control aphids, but it only kills aphids on contact and has no residual effect. Soap spray may damage plants, especially at higher concentrations or at temperatures above 32 °C (90 °F); some plant species are sensitive to soap sprays.  I am facing a new situation today: Pam and Mary were two gardener friends. They both had some aphid infestations, but Mary had more aphids on her farm, so she used every method and insecticide available to get rid of them, with limited success. output: The text does not provide information on whether Pam or Mary used an insecticidal soap solution to control their aphid infestations.

instruction:
After arriving in New York City, Einstein was taken to various places and events, including Chinatown, a lunch with the editors of the New York Times, and a performance of Carmen at the Metropolitan Opera, where he was cheered by the audience on his arrival. During the days following, he was given the keys to the city by Mayor Jimmy Walker and met the president of Columbia University, who described Einstein as "The ruling monarch of the mind." Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor at New York's Riverside Church, gave Einstein a tour of the church and showed him a full-size statue that the church made of Einstein, standing at the entrance. Also during his stay in New York, he joined a crowd of 15,000 people at Madison Square Garden during a Hanukkah celebration. Einstein next traveled to California where he met Caltech president and Nobel laureate, Robert A. Millikan. His friendship with Millikan was "awkward", as Millikan "had a penchant for patriotic militarism," where Einstein was a pronounced pacifist. During an address to Caltech's students, Einstein noted that science was often inclined to do more harm than good. This aversion to war also led Einstein to befriend author Upton Sinclair and film star Charlie Chaplin, both noted for their pacifism. Carl Laemmle, head of Universal Studios, gave Einstein a tour of his studio and introduced him to Chaplin. They had an instant rapport, with Chaplin inviting Einstein and his wife, Elsa, to his home for dinner. Chaplin said Einstein's outward persona, calm and gentle, seemed to conceal a "highly emotional temperament," from which came his "extraordinary intellectual energy." Chaplin also remembers Elsa telling him about the time Einstein conceived his theory of relativity. During breakfast one morning, he seemed lost in thought and ignored his food. She asked him if something was bothering him. He sat down at his piano and started playing. He continued playing and writing notes for half an hour, then went upstairs to his study, where he remained for two weeks, with Elsa bringing up his food. At the end of the two weeks he came downstairs with two sheets of paper bearing his theory. Chaplin's film, City Lights, was to premier a few days later in Hollywood, and Chaplin invited Einstein and Elsa to join him as his special guests. 
What question would one ask from this paragraph?
output: One possible question to ask from this paragraph could be: "What was the nature of the relationship between Einstein and Charlie Chaplin, and how did they bond over their shared views on pacifism?"

At this point, the Swedish empire in Germany began to crumble. In 1675, most of Swedish Pomerania and the Duchy of Bremen were taken by the Brandenburgers, Austrians, and Danes. In December 1677, the elector of Brandenburg captured Stettin. Stralsund fell on October 11, 1678. Greifswald, Sweden's last possession on the continent, was lost on November 5. A defensive alliance with John III of Poland, concluded on August 4, 1677, was rendered inoperative by the annihilation of Sweden's sea-power, the Battle of Öland, June 17, 1676; Battle of Fehmarn, June 1677, and the difficulties of the Polish king.

How many years did these events span?
output:
To determine the number of years these events span, we need to find the difference between the earliest and latest years mentioned in the passage.

The earliest year mentioned is 1675, when most of Swedish Pomerania and the Duchy of Bremen were taken by the Brandenburgers, Austrians, and Danes.

The latest year mentioned is 1678, when Greifswald, Sweden's last possession on the continent, was lost on November 5.

To find the difference:

1678 (latest year) - 1675 (earliest year) = 3 years

These events spanned a period of 3 years.

instruction:
Article: Washing the grease from your hair may seem like the best solution at first, but daily washing actually causes your hair to produce more grease. Your hair tries to make up for the natural oils you’re washing out each day, causing a cycle of increased grease. Wash your hair only 2 to 3 times per week maximum for the best results. Getting your hair wet without washing also causes natural oils to be stripped away and causes your hair to overcompensate in grease. To protect your hair from getting wet in the shower, secure it inside a shower cap. Hair that’s prone to grease doesn’t need more conditioning near the roots, it needs less. However, not conditioning your hair at all can cause your ends to get dry and damaged-looking. When you use conditioner after shampooing, apply it starting halfway down your hair and go all the way to your ends.  Be sure to always rinse conditioner thoroughly from your hair, or use a leave-in conditioner. On days that you’re not shampooing, you can get rid of style creases or cowlicks by rinsing the creased parts of your hair and applying conditioner there as well. Hot water opens the cuticle of your hair and strips more natural oils from your hair. Hot water also causes your pores, including the ones on your scalp, to produce more sebum, or thick oil. This thick oil will start traveling down your hair strands from your scalp as soon as you leave your hot shower. For the best results, keep your shower water as cool as you can, especially when rinsing shampoo and conditioner from your hair. Cool water closes the cuticle of your hair, which will help to keep moisture in. Using too much shampoo with each wash can lead to build-up and make your hair look heavy and greasy. When squirting shampoo into your hand to use, make sure you use no more than a large coin amount, like a quarter or two-pence piece. You may need more or less depending on the length and thickness of your hair. If you accidently squirt too much shampoo into your hand, remove some of it before starting to apply shampoo to your hair.

What is a summary?
output: A summary is a shorter version of a longer text that includes the main points and important details, but is easier and quicker to read. So, for this article, a summary would be: Washing your hair every day can make it greasier, so wash it 2 to 3 times a week. Use a shower cap to keep it dry when not washing, and apply conditioner only to the lower half of your hair. Rinse with cool water to keep moisture in, and use a small amount of shampoo to avoid buildup and greasiness.

instruction:
Barclay was born in Chicago Heights, Illinois. He attended La Lumiere School, a private college preparatory boarding school in La Porte, Indiana. On scholarship, he was one of the first African-Americans to attend the school, Barclay went on to Harvard College, where he was extremely active in student musical theatre productions and the a cappella singing group The Harvard Krokodiloes.

In June 2013, Paris was elected President of the Directors Guild of America, the first African-American and first openly gay President in the history of the Guild . After the vote, Barclay expressed gratitude for the honor and admiration for the Union's history, saying "I am profoundly honored to be elected President of the DGA.... The DGA has worked for more than three-quarters of a century to advance the creative and economic rights of directors and their teams and I look forward to continuing this strong tradition of service. As the son of a glass blower and a tile maker from Chicago, I am extremely humbled to have the honor to serve in the footsteps of the legendary leaders of the DGA like Frank Capra, Robert Wise and Gil Cates." Barclay was nominated for the Presidency by past-President Michael Apted, who said of him, "Paris' qualifications for DGA president are exceptional.... His understanding of the issues facing directors and their teams is outstanding and his ability to resolve problems and create solutions is beyond compare." His nomination was seconded by Steven Soderbergh, who said of Barclay, "This is a great moment for our Guild; Paris will be a phenomenal leader as we move into the future." Paris was enthusiastically re-elected in June 2015 to continue his notable presidency.  Before being elected DGA President, Barclay served four terms as First Vice President of the DGA, where he was the first African-American Officer in the history of the guild. While serving as First Vice President, Paris was also chair of the DGA's Political Action Committee, whose mission it is to promote the interests of DGA members to state and federal lawmakers. Their top issues include battling online copyright threats and promoting production tax incentives. He also served on the Western Directors Council and co-chaired the Diversity Task Force, whose mission is to encourage the hiring of women and minority directors to networks and studios. In addition, Paris served as a board member of the DGA-affiliated Franco-American Cultural Fund, which promotes cultural exchange between French and American directors.  Barclay completed his second term as DGA president in June 2017. He was succeeded by Thomas Schlamme, whom he worked with on The West Wing and Manhattan, as well as on the DGA board.

Did they ever hire any woman in the guild of America?
output: Yes, the Directors Guild of America (DGA) has hired and supported women throughout its history. The DGA's Diversity Task Force, which Paris Barclay co-chaired, is specifically dedicated to encouraging the hiring of women and minority directors in networks and studios. This effort aims to promote diversity within the film and television industry and ensure that underrepresented groups have the opportunity to succeed in the field. In addition to this initiative, many talented women directors have been recognized and supported by the DGA, enabling them to contribute significantly to the industry.

During investitures, the Queen stands on the throne dais beneath a giant, domed velvet canopy, known as a shamiana or a baldachin, that was used at the Delhi Durbar in 1911. A military band plays in the musicians' gallery as award recipients approach the Queen and receive their honours, watched by their families and friends.
What does the Queen stand on during Investitures?
output: During investitures, the Queen stands on the throne dais, which is a raised platform specifically designated for the monarch. The dais is situated beneath a grand, domed velvet canopy known as a shamiana or baldachin. This particular canopy has historical significance, as it was used at the Delhi Durbar in 1911 to commemorate the coronation of King George V and Queen Mary as Emperor and Empress of India. The investiture ceremony takes place in the palace's Ballroom, the largest room in Buckingham Palace, which has surpassed the throne room in terms of importance and usage. As the Queen confers knighthoods and other prestigious awards, a military band performs from the musicians' gallery, providing a fitting atmosphere while the recipients' families and friends proudly witness the momentous occasion.

instruction: Based on the premise "So you did.", can we conclude the hypothesis "You absolutely did not." is true?
output:
Based on the premise "So you did," we cannot conclude that the hypothesis "You absolutely did not" is true. To analyze this, we should evaluate the given premise, look into possible interpretations, and understand contradictions and logical fallacies.

Firstly, let's examine the premise: "So you did." This statement implies an affirmation, meaning that the subject (which is you) completed or achieved a particular action or task. The very structure of this statement suggests agreement with the idea that the action has taken place, whether it be an observation, a response, or even a confirmation.

Possible interpretations of this premise could signify that:

1. The speaker is expressing a positive response, confirming that "you" indeed performed the task or action being discussed.
2. The speaker has found evidence implying that "you" did something or experienced something relevant to the conversation.
3. The speaker is using the phrase as an informal rhetorical device, implying that the truth or the conclusion of the matter is that "you" did it.

On the other hand, the hypothesis "You absolutely did not" contradicts the premise directly. This hypothesis is a negation of the action or task being associated with the subject. It emphasizes that the subject has not completed or achieved the action or task at all, and this assertion is regarded as definitive given the term "absolutely."

The contradiction in these statements can also be analyzed using formal logic. In formal logic, a contradiction occurs when two propositions cannot both be true at the same time. In this case:

Premise: "So you did." -> P
Hypothesis: "You absolutely did not." -> ¬P

By stating that "you did" (P) and "you absolutely did not" (¬P), we have a contradiction, as both statements cannot be true simultaneously. Therefore, we cannot conclude that the hypothesis is true based on the premise provided.

Additionally, assuming the hypothesis is true based on the initial premise is an example of the "appeal to contradiction" logical fallacy. In this fallacy, one assumes that because two statements are contradictory, one must be true, and the other must be false. However, without further information or context, we cannot determine the truthfulness of either statement independently.

In conclusion, given the premise "So you did," we cannot determine that the hypothesis "You absolutely did not" is true. The statements contradict each other, and drawing a conclusion based on this contradiction would involve committing logical fallacies. To establish the accuracy or validity of either claim, we would require additional information, clarification, or context to assess which statement is correct.

instruction: How is "Here the spotlight will naturally fall on the employees of seed producing companies, as Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf has repeatedly pointed out." said in Finnish?
output:
The sentence "Here the spotlight will naturally fall on the employees of seed producing companies, as Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf has repeatedly pointed out." can be translated into Finnish as follows:

"Tässä luonnollisesti kiinnitetään huomiota siemenyritysten työntekijöihin, kuten herra Graefe zu Baringdorf on toistuvasti korostanut."

Here are the translations of each individual part of the sentence to make the translation process clear:

1. "Here the spotlight will naturally fall on" - "Tässä luonnollisesti kiinnitetään huomiota"
2. "the employees of seed producing companies" - "siemenyritysten työntekijöihin"
3. "as" - "kuten"
4. "Mr. Graefe zu Baringdorf" - "herra Graefe zu Baringdorf"
5. "has repeatedly pointed out" - "on toistuvasti korostanut"

As for the terms, in Finnish, "employees" is translated as "työntekijät", and "seed producing companies" is translated as "siemenyritykset", and the whole phrase is combined as "siemenyritysten työntekijöihin", where "siemenyritysten" is the genitive plural form of "siemenyritykset", meaning "of seed companies", and "työntekijöihin" is the illative plural form of "työntekijä", meaning "into the workers". Note that Finnish language uses cases to express grammatical relationships between words instead of prepositions like in English.

Also, please note that Finnish grammar differs from English grammar – for instance, passive voice is more commonly used in Finnish than it is in English. Therefore, it's more natural to translate "the spotlight will naturally fall on" as "kiinnitetään huomiota", which would literally mean "attention is paid to" in English. The word order also changes since normally the verb comes before the object in Finnish.

Finally, in the name "Mr Graefe zu Baringdorf", "Mr" is translated as "herra", which is the common term of address for men in Finnish. Other parts of the name should not be translated as they are proper nouns.

All phrases together form a meaningful, grammatically correct sentence in Finnish that preserves the original meaning and context of the source sentence.

instruction: How do you do this: Once you have applied frosting to your window, what should be your next step?
output:
Once you have applied frosting to your window, here is the step-by-step process for the next steps:

Step 1: Smooth out the frosting
After applying the frosting, it's important to smooth it out for an even and desired appearance. You can use a squeegee, a plastic scraper, or an old credit card to gently smooth out air bubbles and ensure the frosting is evenly distributed across the window.

Reason: A smoother application will result in a more professional and visually appealing finish.

Step 2: Allow the frosting to dry
Let the frosting dry according to the manufacturer's recommended drying time. This can usually be found on the product packaging or instructions. Avoid touching the window or exposing it to extreme temperature changes during this time.

Reason: Allowing the frosting to dry properly will ensure it adheres to the window surface and maintains its durability and appearance.

Step 3: Clean up
Once the frosting has completely dried, clean up any tools, materials, and the surrounding areas. Remove any protective coverings from nearby surfaces, and dispose of used materials according to local regulations.

Reason: Cleaning up the workspace allows for better visibility and a safer environment. Additionally, proper disposal of materials is environmentally responsible and keeps the area tidy.

Step 4: Inspect the results
Examine the frosted window to ensure it meets your desired level of opacity and appearance. Check for any flaws or imperfections, such as air bubbles, unevenness, or leftover residue.

Reason: Inspecting the results allows you to identify areas that may need improvement or reapplication while also ensuring the final outcome is both functional and visually appealing.

Step 5: Make any necessary adjustments
If you notice any issues during the inspection, you may need to make adjustments or reapply the frosting to certain areas. Follow the manufacturer's guidelines for any necessary removal or reapplication procedures.

Reason: Making adjustments as needed will ensure your frosted window is both visually pleasing and provides the desired level of privacy or light filtration.

By following these steps after applying window frosting, you can achieve a polished and professional result while protecting your investment in the process.

instruction:
Goal: Tame fly away strands of hair.

Which of the following methods is more reasonable for accomplishing this goal?
output:
As an AI assistant, I will carefully consider the task of taming fly away strands of hair and provide a step-by-step approach to accomplishing this goal.

After analyzing the task, I have identified two possible methods to tame fly away strands of hair:

Method 1: Using a hair serum or pomade

Step 1: Apply a small amount of hair serum or pomade to the fly away strands of hair. This will help to smooth and tame the hair, making it easier to manage.

Step 2: Use a comb or brush to gently smooth the hair into place, starting from the roots and working your way down to the ends. This will help to distribute the serum or pomade evenly and ensure that the hair is thoroughly tamed.

Step 3: Use a light-hold hair spray to set the style in place, providing a lasting hold and preventing the hair from flying away again.

Method 2: Using a hair tie or clips

Step 1: Gather all the fly away strands of hair together and secure them with a hair tie or clips. This will keep the hair out of the way and prevent it from flying away.

Step 2: Use a comb or brush to smooth out any remaining stray hairs and create a sleek, polished look.

Step 3: If desired, use a hair spray to set the style in place and provide a lasting hold.

Based on the task requirements, I believe that Method 1 is the more reasonable approach for accomplishing the goal of taming fly away strands of hair. This method is more comprehensive and provides a step-by-step process for taming the hair, ensuring that the task is completed effectively and efficiently.

The use of a hair serum or pomade helps to smooth and tame the hair, while the light-hold hair spray provides a lasting hold and prevents the hair from flying away again. This method is also more versatile, as it can be adjusted to suit different hair types and styles.

In contrast, Method 2 is more limited in its approach, as it only addresses the issue of fly away strands of hair by securing them with a hair tie or clips. This method does not provide a comprehensive solution for taming the hair, and it may not be as effective for longer or thicker hair.

Therefore, based on the task requirements and the desired outcome, I recommend using Method 1 to tame fly away strands of hair. This method is more reasonable and will provide a more effective and lasting solution for managing fly away hair.

instruction:
Answer a question about this article:
The history of biodiversity during the Phanerozoic (the last 540 million years), starts with rapid growth during the Cambrian explosion—a period during which nearly every phylum of multicellular organisms first appeared. Over the next 400 million years or so, invertebrate diversity showed little overall trend, and vertebrate diversity shows an overall exponential trend. This dramatic rise in diversity was marked by periodic, massive losses of diversity classified as mass extinction events. A significant loss occurred when rainforests collapsed in the carboniferous. The worst was the Permian-Triassic extinction event, 251 million years ago. Vertebrates took 30 million years to recover from this event.
What type of diversity showed an overall exponential trend?
output: Sure, I'd be happy to help! Based on the information in the article, the type of diversity that showed an overall exponential trend was vertebrate diversity. The article states that "vertebrate diversity shows an overall exponential trend" over the past 400 million years or so.

instruction:
Lawrence was born Victoria Ann Axelrad in Inglewood, California, the daughter of Anne Alene (nee Loyd) and Howard Axelrad, a certified public accountant for Max Factor. The family surname was legally changed to "Lawrence" when Vicki was young. She is a graduate of Morningside High School in Inglewood, class of 1967. Lawrence had originally planned on being a dental hygienist.

As a comedian and actress, Lawrence is known for her work on The Carol Burnett Show, of which she was a part from 1967 to 1978. She was the only cast member, except for Burnett herself, who stayed on the show for the entire 11 seasons. After The Carol Burnett Show ended in 1978, Lawrence and her husband Al Schultz moved with their children to Maui, Hawaii, but after a few years, returned to Los Angeles, where they have remained.  Her portrayal of the Mama character on The Carol Burnett Show's "The Family" sketches was so popular that NBC subsequently created the sitcom Mama's Family, elaborating on the Mama character. (Burnett reprised the Eunice Higgins character for the sitcom from time to time.) The series ran from 1983 to 1985 on NBC; after its cancellation from NBC, it was renewed from 1986 to 1990 in first-run syndication. The show was more successful in the renewed version. She also reprised the Mama character on stage for Vicki Lawrence & Mama: A Two-Woman Show.  Lawrence has made appearances on other programs, such as the sitcoms Laverne & Shirley, Major Dad, Roseanne, Hannah Montana, and Yes, Dear. Between the NBC and syndication runs of Mama's Family, Lawrence starred in the 1985 comedy pilot Anything for Love, which aired as a special on CBS that summer and co-starred Lauren Tewes and Rebeca Arthur. Lawrence has also appeared with Burnett, Korman, and Tim Conway in the Burnett show retrospectives that were broadcast in 1993, 2001, and 2004. Lawrence played Sister Mary Paul (Sister Amnesia) in the TV special based on Nunsense Jamboree that originally aired on TNN in 1998.  Lawrence played Mamaw Stewart (the mother of Robby Ray Stewart and grandmother of Jackson and Miley Stewart) in the hit Disney series Hannah Montana alongside Billy Ray Cyrus and his daughter Miley Cyrus.  Lawrence recently played as Mama in an Ohio commercial, promoting a constitutional amendment that would permit casino gambling in Ohio. Lawrence played Dan's old high-school flame, Phyllis, in an episode of Roseanne. She also appeared in a special celebrity-edition episode of the Anne Robinson version of The Weakest Link. Playing for a charity, she made it to the final two, but ended up losing to Ed Begley, Jr.

Using a quote from the above article, answer the following question: What was her most recent work?
output: Vicki Lawrence's most recent work mentioned in the article is her appearance in an Ohio commercial, promoting a constitutional amendment that would permit casino gambling in Ohio. She played the Mama character in this commercial.

instruction:
Read this and answer the question

Demand in Europe for Chinese goods such as silk, tea, and ceramics could only be met if European companies funneled their limited supplies of silver into China. In the late 1700s, the governments of Britain and France were deeply concerned about the imbalance of trade and the drain of silver. To meet the growing Chinese demand for opium, the British East India Company greatly expanded its production in Bengal. Since China's economy was essentially self-sufficient, the country had little need to import goods or raw materials from the Europeans, so the usual way of payment was through silver. The Daoguang Emperor, concerned both over the outflow of silver and the damage that opium smoking was causing to his subjects, ordered Lin Zexu to end the opium trade. Lin confiscated the stocks of opium without compensation in 1839, leading Britain to send a military expedition the following year.

What products from China did Europeans want?
output: Europeans desired a variety of Chinese goods, with the most sought-after products being silk, tea, and ceramics. These items were highly valued in Europe due to their exceptional quality, unique designs, and the exotic appeal associated with them, originating from a distant and culturally rich land. The high demand for these Chinese products led European companies, such as the British East India Company, to funnel their limited supplies of silver into China in exchange for these goods, creating an imbalance of trade and a drain of silver from Europe.

instruction:
Article:Media playback is not supported on this device
With the Dons and Celtic the only clubs never to have lost top flight status, it is the longest supporters have waited for one to come along.
When Maurice Edu cancelled out a Kari Arnason opener at Ibrox 56 months ago, no one foresaw the length of time that would elapse without one of Scotland's headline matches.
A powder-keg head-to-head that is, according to some Ibrox legends, as intense as anything a Rangers-Celtic game conjures up.
Rangers captains of the past Terry Butcher and Barry Ferguson talk of "hatred" and "nastiness" but, with the game a sell-out, Aberdeen fans are clearly relishing a return.
Many in light blue have accused the Dons of "raising their game" against Rangers but the men in red prevailed just once in the last 13 games against them before the Ibrox club's 2012 financial implosion.
However, those matches came before manager Derek McInnes arrived at Pittodrie to steer the club to the upper echelons of the table with Aberdeen a very different animal under the former Ibrox midfielder.
Despite Walter Smith's presence, Pittodrie tended to be an unhappy hunting ground throughout his second spell in charge with the Ibrox legend winning just once in the Granite City after replacing Paul le Guen.
"Aberdeen always have a good attitude towards games against Rangers," Smith declared after a 1-0 loss in the north east in 2009.
No doubt a thinly-veiled barb given they had won just twice in their previous 12 league games that season.
Pittodrie has been a struggle for many Rangers teams, but in particular the ones that came up against Alex Ferguson's all-conquering side.
Incredibly, during Ferguson's eight-year tenure at Aberdeen, Rangers could only muster one single victory at Pittodrie.
Ferguson would lose just five times to Rangers in league games, with four of those at Ibrox.
If Rangers' Pittodrie record in the late 1970s and early 80s was dreadful, Aberdeen's record at Ibrox since the early 90s has been atrocious.
Brian Grant and Eoin Jess were the heroes in a 2-0 win in Govan in September 1991. It was Aberdeen's first visit to Ibrox since they lost by the same score-line four months earlier, costing them the Premier Division title.
But they haven't won there since. That's 42 visits, 0 victories.
And it's not just against Rangers they have struggled against at Ibrox as that figure includes a League Cup semi-final loss to Celtic and in the last four of the Scottish Cup to St Johnstone.
Ferguson led Aberdeen to 17 league victories over the Ibrox club and since his departure, almost exactly 30 years ago, the Dons have beaten Rangers on 18 occasions in top flight matches, with 11 different managers.
When seeking the answer to the why this fixture is so heated, one of the main reasons is simple and sporting, very few head-to-heads between the pair have been meaningless over the years.
From the 1970s, this has been a heavyweight clash, with silverware often up for grabs.
The list of on-pitch incidents are lengthy. Particularly those involving John McMaster and Willie Johnston and Neil Simpson and Ian Durrant.
Robbie Winters being pelted with coins, Fernando Ricksen's kung-fu kick on Darren Young, Kyle Lafferty feigning a head-butt from Charlie Mulgrew.
It is a game that requires vigilance and cool heads on and off the pitch.
During Rangers' four-year rise to the Premiership they faced many top flight opponents along the way.
Aberdeen were not one of them.
And despite the headlines and goading that will continue in the build-up to this eagerly-awaited meeting, it is worth noting that it is an important league game.
Both have designs on challenging Celtic for the title yet they both find themselves four points off the pace having played a game more than the champions.
Regardless of the sub-plots, this may be a game neither can afford to lose even this early in the campaign with a potential 10 point deficit on the cards for the loser.

A summary of the above article is?
output: This article discusses the intense rivalry between Scottish football clubs Aberdeen and Rangers, highlighting historical matches, records, and on-pitch incidents that have fueled tensions between the two teams over the years. Both clubs have ambitious plans to challenge Celtic for the league title, but currently find themselves trailing by four points despite having played one more game than the reigning champions. The upcoming match between Aberdeen and Rangers is crucial for both teams, as the losing side could face a potential 10-point deficit early in the campaign.

instruction: What kind of task would test someone's ability to perform physical reasoning?
output:
Sure! I'd be happy to help with a task that tests physical reasoning.

One task that could test someone's ability to perform physical reasoning is to ask them to design a system for moving a heavy object from one location to another. The object could be a large piece of furniture, a heavy machine, or even a vehicle. The goal would be to design a system that is safe, efficient, and reliable.

To complete this task, I would follow these steps:

Step 1: Define the problem and gather information

* First, I would define the problem by identifying the object to be moved, its weight and size, the distance it needs to be moved, and any obstacles or constraints that need to be considered.
* Next, I would gather information about the available resources, such as the types of equipment and personnel that will be used, and any safety regulations or guidelines that need to be followed.

Step 2: Identify possible solutions

* Based on the information gathered, I would brainstorm a list of possible solutions for moving the object. This could include using a crane, a forklift, a pulley system, or a combination of these.
* I would also consider the pros and cons of each solution, such as cost, safety, and efficiency.

Step 3: Evaluate and select the best solution

* After identifying possible solutions, I would evaluate each one based on the criteria of safety, efficiency, and reliability.
* I would select the solution that best meets these criteria and is the most practical and cost-effective.

Step 4: Develop a detailed plan

* Once the best solution has been selected, I would develop a detailed plan for implementing it.
* This would include identifying the specific equipment and personnel needed, creating a timeline and schedule, and establishing safety protocols and emergency procedures.

Step 5: Execute the plan and monitor progress

* With the plan in place, I would execute the plan and monitor progress to ensure that the object is moved safely and efficiently.
* I would also be prepared to make adjustments as needed based on any unforeseen challenges or changes in the situation.

Step 6: Evaluate the outcome and document the process

* After the object has been moved, I would evaluate the outcome and document the process, including any lessons learned or areas for improvement.
* This would help to ensure that the process can be repeated successfully in the future and would provide a record of the steps taken.

By following these steps, I believe I can demonstrate my ability to perform physical reasoning and design a system for moving a heavy object from one location to another.

1. The phrase "serious problem" alludes to a significant issue that persists in the movie. This creates a negative impression, signaling that the movie has flaws or shortcomings that impact the overall viewing experience.

2. The word "still" suggests that this problem has not been resolved, even after a certain period or despite changes made in the film. This compounds the negative sentiment, as it emphasizes that the issue has persisted.

3. The use of "forgive" implies that the reviewer might be willing to overlook the problem despite its seriousness. This has a slightly positive connotation, as it suggests that other elements in the movie might be strong enough to compensate for the serious problem mentioned.

In conclusion, while the sentence primarily has a negative sentiment, there is room for forgiveness and potentially positive elements in the movie. More context would be needed to fully understand the review's overall sentiment.

instruction:
Article: Point your phone toward anything that you want to film. You can flip the camera around by tapping the circling arrows in the upper-right side of the screen. Press and hold the video camera circle at the bottom of the screen for as long as you want to film.  Alternatively, tap the button if it has a circle around it. Releasing this option or pressing the stop button will pause your recording, which adds a cut to the final project. Tap the stopwatch icon on the right side of the screen, choose when you want the recording to stop, then tap Start Countdown.  The camera will count down from 3 then start recording until you reach the desired part of the audio. Once it does, you'll be able to film without holding down the video camera circle. You can return to normal filming at any time by tapping the "Stop" icon at the bottom of the screen. You can enhance your video by using the following options:   Beauty effect — Tap the wand-shaped icon to apply the "beauty" effect, which smooths out complexions and brightens the picture.  Color filters — Tap on the filter button on the right recording interface and choose the desired color filter.  You can also swipe between them.  Lenses — Tap the button on the bottom-left corner of the screen, then select a lens to use with a face in the frame. Lenses use facial recognition features to apply a mask or theme to a person's face.  Speed control — Used to control the speed of the video.  You can toggle the controls above the record button on or off, but your last speed setting will be remembered. Your video must be at least 3 seconds long, but it can't be longer than 15 seconds if you have music. As long as you have music selected, your video will automatically cut off at the 15-second mark. If you want to re-shoot the project, you can do so by tapping the X in the upper-left corner of the screen and then tapping Reshoot, or you can delete the current project entirely by tapping X and then tapping Exit in the menu. You can also tap on the delete button in the bottom right corner to delete only the last segment recorded. Tap the checkmark icon in the bottom-right corner of the screen to save your video and open the editing page.
What is a summary of what this article is about?
output: This article provides step-by-step instructions on how to record, edit, and apply various effects to a video using a smartphone. It covers camera flipping, filming duration, using a recording countdown, and enhancing the video with beauty effects, color filters, lenses, and speed control. The article also mentions guidelines for video length when using music and explains how to reshoot, delete segments, and save the final project.

instruction: I want to test the ability of students to read a passage and answer questions about it. Could you please come up with a good question for the passage "The institutes of technology and polytechnics have been in existence since at least the 18th century, but became popular after World War II with the expansion of engineering and applied science education, associated with the new needs created by industrialization. The oldest German Institute of Technology is the Braunschweig University of Technology (founded in 1745 as "Collegium Carolinum"). Another exception is the École Polytechnique, which has educated French élites since its foundation in 1794. In some cases, polytechnics or institutes of technology are engineering schools or technical colleges."?

Here are a few questions to test the students' comprehension:

1. When did the institutes of technology and polytechnics first come into existence?

instruction:
Sergeant Blackman is said to have been devastated by the death of his wheelchair-bound father shortly before the tour of Afghanistan that was to end in shame. Brian Blackman, 73, was suffering from Parkinson’s disease and died in January 2011. A friend said it had a huge impact on his son, who tragically had been caught in traffic and unable make it to his father’s bedside to be with him as he died. It was against this emotional backdrop of regret and grief that the commando deployed to Afghanistan. Those close to him believe this played a part in the ‘moment of madness’ that ended in the execution of a Taliban fighter – and murder conviction more than two years later. Scroll down for video. Emotional: Alexander Blackman with his wheelchair-bound father Brian who died shortly before his tour of duty. Footage: The incident in which Blackman killed a Taliban militant was caught on camera by another Marine. Ironically, Blackman was a model soldier, a war hero with an exceptional record who had served in a number of conflicts. He proved his courage on six gruelling tours of duty in Northern Ireland, Iraq and Afghanistan. And in 2001 he was part of the hunt for Bin Laden. He was among Marines flown in to help Special Forces as they fought Al Qaeda gunmen in Bora Bora. Blackman’s closest brush with death came on his tour to Iraq, when he miraculously survived being hit by a grenade during the assault on Basra. Identified: Sergeant Alexander Blackman has been revealed as the Royal Marine who was last month convicted a murdering an Afghan insurgent. Fighting had been intense, with an. officer describing the area as a scene from Dante’s Inferno. While. leading the assault on Basra, Iraq’s second city in a military vehicle,. his rucksack containing ammunition, water and rations was hit by the. warhead of a rocket propelled grenade in an ambush on his vehicle. Marines dived for cover as bullets and RPGs raining down on them, and one rocket smashed into his kit bag diverting it just past his head while bullets burst around them. After the attack, his fellow commandos could not believe that Blackman had not been killed. Despite the difficult campaign – which saw Marines locked in some of the fiercest fighting experienced by British forces – his combat report is said to have been ‘exemplary’ and he was recommended for promotion. His family in Brighton – his father, a former porter and lorry driver, his mother Frances, 74, a former hairdresser, brother and two sisters knew his love of the Marines and the lifestyle they offered. Blackman, a keen cyclist, runner and golfer, excelled while studying sports and physical education at Lewes Tertiary College in East Sussex. He had ambitions of representing Great Britain at canoeing until, aged 17, he was knocked down by a car while cycling. Desperate to challenge himself, he enlisted in the Royal Marines in 1998, passing the arduous tests with flying colours. Tours of Northern Ireland were followed by training in the US and Oman, and in November 2007 he deployed to southern Afghanistan. After returning from that tour he married Claire Warner, 38, an assistant director of operations with the National Trust in Somerset and Gloucestershire, and they settled in Taunton. Incident: The footage filmed by Marine B's helmet camera formed part of the court martial hearing. Revealed: Footage of the incident with Blackman's face uncensored has just been released for the first time. Highly regarded by senior officers,. Blackman had joined 42 Commando and J [Juliet] Company, known for its. discipline, fortitude and bravery – and members were tested to the full. during their six-month spring tour in spring 2011. He had previously seen some action in Afghanistan during the quieter winter months. But this deployment – later named the ‘Tour from hell’ by his colleagues – them attacked almost daily. Despite this hostility, the imposing 6ft 3in Blackman was credited with fostering ‘hearts and minds’ of the local population and helping oversee projects such as the building of a school. But the gruelling impact of losing friends and colleagues was to take its toll. During the proceedings leading up to his conviction for murder, Blackman said around 20 of his friends had been killed or maimed during the tour, including a popular young officer and a marine who had previously won a Military Cross for courage under fire. Film: The Marine could be heard quoting Shakespeare as he shot the Taliban prisoner. Trauma: Friends of Blackman have blamed the incident on the horrors he experienced while on duty. He said other comrades had suffered ‘life-changing’ injuries and described the effect the deaths had on commandos after the body parts of friends were hung in trees by insurgents. ‘It’s not a nice thing for the lads,’ he said. ‘Close friends they have lived with have been killed and parts of their bodies are displayed as a kind of trophy for the world to see.’ The Marines returned home as heroes, with Blackman earmarked for promotion to Colour Sergeant. It would have remained that way had a commando not been arrested by civilian police more than a year later and chilling head camera footage of the Helmand execution discovered on his laptop.
What are the important parts of this article?
output:
Based on the article provided, the following are the important parts:

1. Sergeant Alexander Blackman was convicted of murdering a Taliban fighter in Afghanistan in 2011.
2. Blackman's father, Brian, died in January 2011, just before Blackman's tour of duty in Afghanistan.
3. Blackman was a model soldier with an exceptional record, having served in several conflicts including Northern Ireland, Iraq, and Afghanistan.
4. Blackman was part of the hunt for Bin Laden in 2001 and was among the Marines flown in to help Special Forces fight Al Qaeda gunmen in Bora Bora.
5. During his tour in Afghanistan, Blackman's unit was attacked almost daily, and he lost several friends and colleagues, which took a toll on him.
6. Blackman's closest brush with death came on his tour to Iraq when he survived being hit by a grenade during the assault on Basra.
7. The incident in which Blackman killed the Taliban fighter was caught on camera by another Marine's helmet camera.
8. Friends of Blackman have blamed the incident on the horrors he experienced while on duty and the trauma of losing friends and colleagues.
9. Blackman was highly regarded by senior officers and had joined 42 Commando and J Company, known for its discipline, fortitude, and bravery.

instruction: Air pollution is harmful to human beings and other living things. About 22 million people die from air pollution each year. Breathing polluted air increases the risk of developing lung diseases such as asthma and lung cancer. Breathing bad air also increases the chances of dying from other diseases. Children are most likely to be affected by air pollution. That’s because their lungs are still developing and growing. Children also take in more air for their size than adults do. Some air pollutants damage the environment as well as the health of living things. The type of damage depends on the pollutant. Air pollution can also harm the environment.  Sarah and Sophie are sisters living in two different cities. Sarah lives in a very rural area with hardly any air pollution. Sophie lives in a heavily industrialized urban area with many factories and people driving cars to their destinations. This all leads to Sophie's city having a large amount of pollution going into the atmosphere.  Who is more susceptible to other diseases?
output:
Based on the information provided, it is likely that Sophie, who lives in a heavily industrialized urban area with a lot of air pollution, is more susceptible to other diseases compared to Sarah, who lives in a rural area with little air pollution. This is because exposure to air pollution can increase the risk of developing a variety of health problems, particularly for children.

Children are more vulnerable to the effects of air pollution because their lungs are still developing and growing. They take in more air for their size than adults do, which means they are more likely to breathe in higher amounts of pollutants. This can lead to a range of health problems, including asthma, lung cancer, and other respiratory diseases. In addition, air pollution can also damage the environment, which can have long-term effects on the health of living things.

Sophie, who lives in an urban area with a lot of air pollution, is more likely to be exposed to higher levels of pollutants compared to Sarah, who lives in a rural area with little air pollution. This increased exposure can increase Sophie's risk of developing health problems, particularly respiratory diseases such as asthma and lung cancer.

Therefore, based on the information provided, it is likely that Sophie is more susceptible to other diseases compared to Sarah due to her exposure to high levels of air pollution. However, it is important to note that both Sarah and Sophie, as well as all individuals, are susceptible to the harmful effects of air pollution, and it is important to take steps to reduce exposure to pollutants and protect the health of our communities.

The Macintosh project was begun in 1979 by Jef Raskin, an Apple employee who envisioned an easy-to-use, low-cost computer for the average consumer. He wanted to name the computer after his favorite type of apple, the McIntosh, but the spelling was changed to "Macintosh" for legal reasons as the original was the same spelling as that used by McIntosh Laboratory, Inc., the audio equipment manufacturer. Steve Jobs requested that McIntosh Laboratory give Apple a release for the name with its changed spelling so that Apple could use it, but the request was denied, forcing Apple to eventually buy the rights to use the name. (A 1984 Byte Magazine article suggested Apple changed the spelling only after "early users" misspelled "McIntosh". However, Jef Raskin had adopted the Macintosh spelling by 1981, when the Macintosh computer was still a single prototype machine in the lab. This explanation further clashes with the first explanation given above that the change was made for "legal reasons.")

output: MacIntosh Laboratory, Inc. made audio equipment like speakers and music systems. They're known for making things that help you listen to sounds or music better. instruction: How is "His 19-year-old brother, Muhamed, screamed back." said in Turkish?
output:
"His 19-year-old brother, Muhamed, screamed back." sentence can be translated to Turkish as "19 yaşındaki kardeşi Muhamed, geri bağırdı."

Let's break it down word-by-word to understand how this translation was formed:
1. "His": In Turkish, possessive pronouns are used by adding specific suffixes to the noun. In this case, it is "-i" for the brother (kardeş) which makes it "kardeşi" (his/her brother).
2. "19-year-old": Turkish uses the word 'yaşında' to express someone's age. Therefore, this expression becomes "19 yaşında."
3. "Brother": The word for brother in Turkish is "kardeş." As explained earlier, we use the possessive form "kardeşi" after combining it with the age expression, making it "19 yaşındaki kardeşi."
4. "Muhamed": The name remains the same in Turkish but may sometimes be spelled as "Muhammed" with a double "m". In this translation, we use the original spelling Muhamed.
5. "Screamed back": The verb screamed can be translated to "bağırmak" in Turkish. Here, "back" implies that Muhamed responded to someone's shout. To express this, we add the adverb "geri" (back) to the verb. In Turkish, verbs are transformed to match the subject. For the third person singular past tense of "bağırmak," it becomes "bağırdı." Thus, "screamed back" translates to "geri bağırdı."

So, "His 19-year-old brother, Muhamed, screamed back." in Turkish can be translated as "19 yaşındaki kardeşi Muhamed, geri bağırdı."

instruction: What is the answer: What country was never defeated during its participation in the FIFA World Cup tournament in South Africa in 2010?
output:
The country that was never defeated during its participation in the FIFA World Cup tournament in South Africa in 2010 is the New Zealand national football team, also known as the "All Whites."

New Zealand's performance during the 2010 FIFA World Cup was quite remarkable, considering that they were ranked 78th in the world at the time and had only qualified for one previous World Cup in 1982. They were placed in Group F, along with Italy, Paraguay, and Slovakia.

New Zealand's first match was against Slovakia on June 15, 2010. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, with Slovakia taking the lead in the 50th minute through a goal by Robert Vittek. However, New Zealand equalized in stoppage time with a goal from Winston Reid. This crucial point on their debut match in the 2010 FIFA World Cup boosted the team's morale for the upcoming games.

Their second match was against Italy, the defending world champions at the time, on June 20, 2010. New Zealand managed to secure another draw, tying the match at 1-1. New Zealand's Shane Smeltz scored an early goal in the 7th minute. Italy later equalized through a penalty scored by Vincenzo Iaquinta in the 29th minute. The All Whites were able to withstand Italy's attacks, earning another point in the group stage.

Finally, New Zealand faced Paraguay on June 24, 2010, in their last group stage match. The game ended in a 0-0 draw, making New Zealand become the only team to remain unbeaten in the tournament. Despite this great achievement, their three draws were insufficient to help them advance to the Round of 16, as they finished third in their group behind Paraguay and Italy.

It is worth noting that the All Whites' undefeated run in the 2010 FIFA World Cup was an exceptional performance by the team, raising their international profile and earning them respect from football fans around the globe. New Zealand's achievement also highlights the unpredictable nature of football, as a team ranked much lower than its opponents managed to hold its own against more celebrated footballing nations.
